column1: Node.js is an open-source
column2: cross-platform JavaScript run-time environment that executes JavaScript code outside of a browser.

column1: JavaScript is used primarily for client-side scripting
column2: in which scripts written in JavaScript are embedded in a webpage's HTML and run client-side by a JavaScript engine in the user's web browser.

column1: Node.js lets developers use JavaScript to write command line tools and for server-side scripting—running scripts server-side to produce dynamic web page content before the page is sent to the user's web browser.
Consequently
column2: Node.js represents a "JavaScript everywhere" paradigm
column3: unifying web application development around a single programming language
column4: rather than different languages for server side and client side scripts.

column1: Though .js is the conventional filename extension for JavaScript code
column2: the name "Node.js" does not refer to a particular file in this context and is merely the name of the product.

column1: Node.js has an event-driven architecture capable of asynchronous I/O.
These design choices aim to optimize throughput and scalability in web applications with many input/output operations
column2: as well as for real-time Web applications (e.g.
column3: real-time communication programs and browser games).

column1: The Node.js distributed development project
column2: governed by the Node.js Foundation
column3: is facilitated by the Linux Foundation's Collaborative Projects program.

column1: In natural language processing
column2: latent Dirichlet allocation (LDA) is a generative statistical model that allows sets of observations to be explained by unobserved groups that explain why some parts of the data are similar.

column1: For example
column2: if observations are words collected into documents
column3: it posits that each document is a mixture of a small number of topics and that each word's presence is attributable to one of the document's topics.

column1: LDA is an example of a topic model.
In the context of population genetics
column2: LDA was proposed by J. K. Pritchard
column3: M. Stephens and P. Donnelly in 2000.

column1: In the context of machine learning
column2: where it is most widely applied today
column3: LDA was rediscovered independently by David Blei
column4: Andrew Ng and Michael I. Jordan in 2003
column5: and presented as a graphical model for topic discovery.

column1: In LDA
column2: each document may be viewed as a mixture of various topics where each document is considered to have a set of topics that are assigned to it via LDA.
